oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Letter from Bradford Dallas to Elise Croft about labor contracts
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Letter from Bradford Dallas in which he frankly explains the labor contract with workers and its impact on the chimney business. The company had to double the wages of workers and hire additional men, which raised the cost of making chimneys. He discusses the recent tax structure changes, saying they are "an improvement on the old methods." He includes a list of jobs for the year and each job's profit.

Bradford B. Dallas (b. 1924) is the son of Charles Frederick Dallas, who was owner of the Antillean Construction Company based in Havana. Bradford managed his father's company and William Croft's General Concrete Construction Company of Cuba until he was forced to leave the country in 1961.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Dallas, Bradford B.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Cuba--Politics and government; Labor contract; Chimney cleaning industry; Taxation
Laborers; Contract laborers; Employees; Chimney sweeps
